summary: Paul Wallach served as the Chief Counsel of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence. He was involved in the investigation of intelligence activities, including those related to the JFK assassination. Wallach's role included interviewing individuals connected to intelligence operations, such as Bruce Cheever, and participating in meetings with CIA officials to discuss access to Lee Harvey Oswald case files. He was also involved in discussions regarding proposed restrictions on the CIA's operational use of academics and grantees. The documents indicate his active involvement in the Senate Select Committee's efforts to investigate intelligence matters and the JFK assassination.
significance: As Chief Counsel of the Senate Select Committee on Intelligence, Paul Wallach played a crucial role in the investigation of intelligence activities related to the JFK assassination. He was involved in interviewing key individuals, negotiating access to sensitive files, and shaping the committee's understanding of the events surrounding the assassination.
